This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $DNF$ is a subset of $DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.
It is well-known that some $DNF$ formulas (i.e. the parity function $PARITY_n=\bigoplus_{i=1}^n x_i$) have exponentially many prime implicates.

MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bodlaender_1993}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from DNF to nFBDD.
DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from DNF to NNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If DNF transforms to SDD in polynomial time, then DNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then DNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

uOBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNF transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time, then DNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in polynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If DNF transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If DNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then DNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018,Van den Broeck_2015}.
Proposition 7 of \citet{Bova_2016} shows that the Sauerhoff function $S_n$ has $DNNF$ size $O(n^2)$. Theorem 9 shows that $S_n$ has $d$-$DNNF$ size $2^{\Omega(n)}$.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2000}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: Section 5 of \citet{Bodlaender_1993} extends the compilation of $dec$-$DNNF$s into $FBDD$s (shown in \citet{Beame_2013}) to show that $DNNF$ can be quasipolynomial-time compiled into $nFBDD$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Section 5 of \citet{Bodlaender_1993} extends the compilation of $dec$-$DNNF$s into $FBDD$s (shown in \citet{Beame_2013}) to show that $DNNF$ can be quasipolynomial-time compiled into $nFBDD$.
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $DNNF$ is a subset of $NNF$, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If DNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If DNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If DNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If DNNF transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time, then DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that DNNF cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If DNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2000}.

d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If DNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If FBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

cSDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $FBDD$ is a subset of $d$-$DNNF$, so a polynomial transformation is trivial.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If FBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to DNNF.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If FBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If FBDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.
FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to nFBDD.

FBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from FBDD to NNF.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Capelli_2016,Pipatsrisawat_2010}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If FBDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If FBDD transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.
Appendix D.2 of \citet{Pipatsrisawat_2010} and Section 6.3 of \citet{Capelli_2016} independently proved this result using different techniques.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $FBDD$ is the subset of $uFBDD$ with no $\vee$-nodes.

uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.
The hidden weighted bit function $HWB_n$ has $OBDD$ size $2^{\Omega(n/4)}$ \citep{Bryant_1986} but $FBDD$ size $O(n^2)$ \citep{Gergov_1994}.

Rewrite each decision node labeled $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0$ and $D_1$ are the rewritings of the 0- and 1-successors. The introduced $\vee$-gates are decision gates and the $\wedge$-gates are decomposable, so all $\vee$-gates arise from decision node rewrites, yielding a $dec$-$DNNF$ in linear time \citep{Amarilli_2018}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If FBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

While \citet{Darwiche_2002} cites specific examples like the negation of the pairwise DNF $\Pi_n$, the exponential blowup is fundamentally a structural translation issue: distributing a $DNF$ (of which $IP$ is a subset) into a $CNF$ inherently risks an exponential explosion of clauses.
This is listed as an open problem in the Knowledge Compilation Map (2002).
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $IP$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to DNNF.

The negation of the clique detection function $\neg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has $O(n^3)$ prime implicates (hence polynomial $IP$ size), but any $FBDD$ for $\neg\Sigma_{n,k}$ has exponential size for suitable $k$ \citep{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.
The $OR_n$ function $\bigvee_{i=1}^nx_i$ can be represented in $O(n)$ as a $IP$ formula but has $2^n-1$ models.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to nFBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bodlaender_1993}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from IP to nFBDD.

IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from IP to NNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If IP transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If IP transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If IP transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.

dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If IP transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If IP transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then IP transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that IP cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Wegener_1987}.
A Shannon tree for any $MODS$ formula can be generated in polynomial time. Paths from the root to 0-leaves yield a $CNF$ representation \citep{Darwiche_2002}.
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $MODS$ is a subset of $d$-$DNNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to d-SDNNF.
As defined by \citet{Darwiche_2002}, $MODS$ is a subset of $DNF$. Therefore, a polynomial transformation is trivial.
MODS transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to DNNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to FBDD.
The Quine-McCluskey algorithm generates an $IP$ formula in polynomial time.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to nFBDD.

MODS transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. d-DNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to NNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to nOBDD.
A Shannon tree for any $MODS$ formula following order $<$ can be generated in polynomial time. This tree can be reduced into a corresponding $OBDD_<$ in polynomial time \citep{Darwiche_2002}.

\citet{Kaleyski_2016} constructs a family of Boolean functions $\psi_i$ with $MODS$ size $\Theta(2^{2i})$ but $PI$ size $\Omega(2^{(i-1)^2/4})$, ruling out a polynomial transformation. Whether an exponential separation exists remains open.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2011}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to SDD.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to SDNNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to uFBDD.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to uOBDD.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to OBDD.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to dec-DNNF.

MODS transforms to OBDD$_<$ in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from MODS to dec-SDNNF.

d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If nFBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If nFBDD transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018,Van den Broeck_2015}.
The Sauerhoff function has an $nFBDD$ of size $O(n^2)$ over $n^2$ variables, but as a $d$-$DNNF$ has size $2^{\Omega(n)}$.

d-DNNF transforms to nFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If nFBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. CNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from PI to NNF.

nOBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bova_2016}.

SDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. uOBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If PI transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then PI transforms to d-DNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that PI cannot transform to d-DNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. If SDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to d-DNNF.
$SDD$ is a strict subset of $d$-$SDNNF$.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. If SDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to DNNF.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nFBDD.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to NNF.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to nOBDD.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to OBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that SDD cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bryant_1986,Bova_2016_a}.

OBDD$_<$ transforms to SDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Darwiche_2011}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then OBDD$_<$ transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that OBDD$_<$ cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDD to SDNNF.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to uFBDD.

SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDD to uOBDD.
$OBDD$ representations of $HWB_n$ are $2^{\Omega(n)}$\citet{Bryant_1986}, but an $SDD$ can represent $HWB_n$ in size $O(n^3)$\citet{Bova_2016_a}.

dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If SDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then SDD transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that SDD cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Bryant_1986,Bova_2016_a}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a structured $DNNF$ is a triple of the corresponding $DNNF$, the v-tree $T$, and a mapping $\rho$; as such, extracting a $DNNF$ from a $SDNNF$ is trivial.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

noPolyDescription.description: d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

quasiDescription.description: SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to nFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to nFBDD.
SDNNF transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from SDNNF to NNF.

noPolyDescription.description: d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD$_<$ in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. PI transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to PI in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If SDNNF transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

nOBDD transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then nOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that nOBDD cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-SDNNF transforms to SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015,Darwiche_2002}. If SDNNF transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to OBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015,Darwiche_2002}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to cSDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to cSDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to cSDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018,Van den Broeck_2015}.

Rewrite each decision node labeled $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0, D_1$ are the rewritings of the 0- and 1-successors. The $\wedge$-gates are decomposable, and unambiguity of the $uFBDD$ ensures all introduced $\vee$-gates are deterministic, yielding a $d$-$DNNF$ in linear time \citep{Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uFBDD to DNNF.
The parity-row/parity-column functions $\phi_n \vee \psi_n$ have $uFBDD$ size $O(n^2)$ (Proposition 3.1, \citet{Amarilli_2018}) but $FBDD$ size $2^{\Omega(n^{1/2})}$ \citep{Bova_2016,Wegener_2000}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uFBDD transforms to IP in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. MODS transforms to CNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If uFBDD transforms to MODS in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $uFBDD$ is the subset of $nFBDD$ satisfying unambiguity.

uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. DNNF transforms to NNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uFBDD to NNF.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. OBDD$_<$ transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to OBDD$_<$ in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. SDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Van den Broeck_2015}. If uFBDD transforms to SDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. SDNNF transforms to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uFBDD transforms to SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to nOBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to nOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. uOBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. OBDD transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to OBDD in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. If uFBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to FBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2000}.

d-DNNF transforms to uFBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}. dec-SDNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If uFBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-DNNF transforms to d-SDNNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-DNNF cannot transform to d-SDNNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to d-DNNF.

Construct a right-linear v-tree from the variable order, then rewrite each decision node labeled $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0, D_1$ are the rewritings of the 0- and 1-successors. The v-tree alignment ensures structuredness, and unambiguity of the $uOBDD$ makes all introduced $\vee$-gates deterministic, yielding a $d$-$SDNNF$ in linear time \citep{Amarilli_2018}.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. If uOBDD transforms to DNF in quasipolynomial time, then d-SDNNF transforms to DNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

uOBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. nFBDD transforms to DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from uOBDD to DNNF.

d-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. IP transforms to DNF in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. This contradicts the fact that d-SDNNF cannot transform to DNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002,Amarilli_2018}.

As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $uOBDD$ is the subset of $nOBDD$ satisfying unambiguity.

As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $uOBDD$ is the subset of $uFBDD$ satisfying an order of the variables.
The hidden weighted bit function $HWB_n$ has polynomial $uOBDD$ size, but $OBDD$ size $2^{\Omega(n)}$ \citep{Amarilli_2018}.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to d-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to d-DNNF.

The function $\bigwedge_{i=1}^n(x_i\Leftrightarrow y_i)$ has an $OBDD_<$ representation of size polynomial in $n$ whenever $<$ satisfies $x_1<y_1<...<x_n<y_n$ but exponential in $n$ if $<$ satisfies $x_1<x_2<...<x_n<y_1<y_2<...<y_n$

As established by \citet{Darwiche_2011}, which introduced SDDs as a new central canonical representation, every $OBDD$ is a right-linear $SDD$. Thus, $SDD$ strictly generalizes $OBDD$.

OBDD transforms to dec-SDNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a polynomial transformation exists from OBDD to dec-DNNF.

Construct a right-linear v-tree from the variable order, then rewrite each decision node labeled $x$ as $(x \wedge D_0) \vee (\neg x \wedge D_1)$, where $D_0, D_1$ are the rewritings of the 0- and 1-successors. The v-tree alignment ensures structuredness, and since all $\vee$-gates arise from decision node rewrites, every $\vee$-gate is a decision gate, yielding a $dec$-$SDNNF$ in linear time \citep{Amarilli_2018}.

FBDD transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-DNNF transforms to CNF in quasipolynomial time, then FBDD transforms to CNF in at most quasi-polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that FBDD cannot transform to CNF in quasipolynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}.

As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, $dec$-$DNNF$ is the subset of $d$-$DNNF$ satisfying the decision property.

FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to uFBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
uFBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNF transforms to dec-DNNF in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. dec-DNNF transforms to FBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Beame_2013}. FBDD transforms to uFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to uFBDD.

noPolyDescription.description: uOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to uOBDD.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
uOBDD transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to nFBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to nFBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in at worst quasipolynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Bollig_2018,Beame_2015}. OBDD transforms to uOBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018}. Therefore a quasi-polynomial transformation exists from dec-SDNNF to uOBDD.

noPolyDescription.description: OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

quasiDescription.description: Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.

matrix.description:
First, we show no polynomial transformation exists.
OBDD transforms to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Darwiche_2002}. If dec-SDNNF transforms to OBDD in polynomial time, then dec-SDNNF transforms to FBDD in polynomial time. This contradicts the fact that dec-SDNNF cannot transform to FBDD in polynomial time \citet{Amarilli_2018,Beame_2013}.

Now, we show a quasipolynomial transformation exists.
Theorem 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that $SDNNF$ can be compiled into $nOBDD$ by adapting the compilation of \citet{Beame_2015} from $DNNF$ to $nFBDD$; proposition 2 of \citet{Bollig_2018} shows that this $nOBDD$ is unambiguous if the $SDNNF$ is deterministic. Additionally, the same compilation yields an $OBDD$ if the input is a $dec$-$SDNNF$ since there are no $\vee$-gates that are not decision gates in a $dec$-$SDNNF$.
As defined by \citet{Amarilli_2018}, a $dec$-$SDNNF$ is simply a structured $dec$-$DNNF$, so discarding the v-tree completes the transformation.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \vee x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: Requires that in each pair $(x_{2i}, x_{2i+1})$, at least one is true. Dual to the Pairwise DNF.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Pi_n = \bigvee_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( x_{2i} \wedge x_{2i+1} \right)$
separatingFunctions.description: Requires that at least one pair $(x_{2i}, x_{2i+1})$ has both variables true. Dual to the Pairwise CNF.

separatingFunctions.name: Parity function
separatingFunctions.description: $O_n = \bigoplus_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i$ has linear size $OBBD_<$ representations but exponential size CNF and DNF representations.

separatingFunctions.name: Hidden Weighted Bit
separatingFunctions.description: Let $w = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i$ be the Hamming weight of the input. Then $HWB_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n) = x_w$ (the $w$-th input bit). Has $OBDD$ size $2^{\Omega(n)}$ but polynomial $SDD$ and $FBDD$ size.

separatingFunctions.name: $OR_n = \bigvee_{i=1}^{n} x_i$
separatingFunctions.description: Separates languages that compactly represent disjunctions from those that cannot.

separatingFunctions.name: $\Sigma_n = \bigwedge_{i=1}^n (x_i \leftrightarrow y_i)$
separatingFunctions.description: Requires that each pair $(x_i, y_i)$ has equal truth values. An $OBDD_<$ with interleaved order $x_1 < y_1 < \cdots < x_n < y_n$ is polynomial, but a separated order $x_1 < \cdots < x_n < y_1 < \cdots < y_n$ forces exponential size.

separatingFunctions.name: Clique Detection Instances
separatingFunctions.description: Tests whether a directed graph on $n$ vertices (encoded as $I \in \{0,1\}^{n^2}$) contains a bidirectional clique of size $k$: $\Sigma_{n,k}(I) = 1 \iff I$ contains such a clique. Has $O(n^3)$ prime implicants but exponential $FBDD$ size for suitable $k$.

separatingFunctions.name: Sauerhoff function
separatingFunctions.description: Let $g_n: \{0,1\}^{2n} \to \{0,1\}$ be the function evaluating to 1 if and only if the sum of its inputs is divisible by 3. The Sauerhoff function $S_n: \{0,1\}^{n^2} \to \{0,1\}$ is defined on the $n \times n$ matrix $X = (x_{i,j})$ as $S_n(X) = R_n(X) \vee C_n(X)$, where $R_n, C_n : \{0,1\}^{n^2} \to \{0,1\}$ are defined by $R_n(X) = \bigplus_{i=1}^n g_n(x_{i1},x_{i2},...,x_{in}$ and $C_n(X) = R_n(X^T)$.

separatingFunctions.name: Jukna-Schnitger function
separatingFunctions.description: Tests triangle-freeness on graphs with respect to a fixed set of forbidden triangles $A \subset T_n$. \citet{Jukna_2002} show that for every $n$, there exists $A_n$ of size $O(n^2)$ such that any balanced rectangle cover of $JS_n^{A_n}$ has size $2^{\Omega(n^2)}$. Has $PI$ size $O(n^2)$ but $DNNF$ size $2^{\Omega(n^2)}$.

operationLemmas.description: CO and CD imply ME: First test consistency (polytime via CO). If inconsistent, return the empty set. Otherwise, build a decision tree of models by iterating over variables $x_1, \ldots, x_n$ and using CD to test consistency of $\Sigma | \alpha \land x_i$ and $\Sigma | \alpha \land \neg x_i$ for each leaf term $\alpha$. Since one branch must succeed for consistent terms, the tree has $O(mn)$ tests where $m$ is the model count and $n$ is the variable count.
CO and CD imply CE: To test whether sentence $\Sigma$ entails non-valid clause $\alpha$, i.e. $\Sigma \models \alpha$, it suffices to test whether $\Sigma | \neg\alpha$ is inconsistent.

VA and CD imply IM: To test whether consistent term $\alpha$ entails sentence $\Sigma$, i.e. $\alpha \models \Sigma$, test whether $
eg\alpha \lor \Sigma$ is valid. This is equivalent to $
eg\alpha \lor (\Sigma | \alpha)$. Since $
eg\alpha$ and $\Sigma | \alpha$ share no variables, the disjunction is valid iff $
eg\alpha$ is valid or $\Sigma | \alpha$ is valid. Since $\alpha$ is consistent, $
eg\alpha$ cannot be valid. Thus we test validity of $\Sigma | \alpha$, constructible in polytime via CD and testable in polytime via VA.
EQ implies CO: $\mathsf{true}$ and $\mathsf{false}$ belong to every NNF subset. $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff it is equivalent to $\mathsf{false}$.
EQ implies VA: $\mathsf{true}$ and $\mathsf{false}$ belong to every NNF subset. $\Sigma$ is valid iff it is equivalent to $\mathsf{true}$.
SE implies EQ: Sentences $\Sigma_1$ and $\Sigma_2$ are equivalent iff $\Sigma_1 \models \Sigma_2$ and $\Sigma_2 \models \Sigma_1$.
CT implies CO: Model counting (CT) requires enumerating all satisfying assignments. If a formula is inconsistent, it has zero models. Thus CT can determine CO by checking if the model count is zero.
CT implies VA: A formula is valid iff all $2^n$ assignments satisfy it. If we can count models in polytime (CT), we can check validity by testing if the count equals $2^n$.

IM implies VA: A formula $\Sigma$ is valid iff the complete term (all positive or all negative literals, i.e., any single model) implies $\Sigma$. Since IM tests whether a consistent term implies the sentence, testing with a trivially consistent term gives validity.
CE implies CO: A formula $\Sigma$ is inconsistent iff $\Sigma \models \bot$, which is equivalent to $\Sigma$ entailing the empty clause. Clause entailment (CE) can test this directly.

ME implies CO: Model Enumeration requires outputting all models in time polynomial in the input size and number of models. In particular, it must determine whether any model exists (output the first model or halt with the empty set) in polynomial time, which is exactly the Consistency (CO) query.
